title: 110_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" and includes reforms to the USERRA complaint process. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to ensure prompt notification of rights to complainants and provide technical assistance upon request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints within 90 days of receipt by the Secretary. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints within 90 days of receipt by the Secretary. Not later than 15 days after receiving a complaint, the Secretary must refer it to the Attorney General or special counsel. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" requires the Secretary to refer complaints to the Attorney General within 15 days. The Attorney General must make a decision within 45 days of receiving the referral. The Attorney General must decide whether to represent a person within 45 days of receiving a referral under the USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007. The Special Counsel also has 45 days to decide on initiating an action and representing a person before the Merit Systems Protection Board. The Attorney General and the Special Counsel must decide within 45 days whether to represent a person before the Merit Systems Protection Board under the USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WITH RESPECT TO ENFORCEMENT OF USERRA. The Secretary of Defense will now include the number of cases reviewed through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report. The Secretary of Defense will include the number of cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve in the annual report, including cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment and disability-related issues. The Secretary of Defense will report on cases involving disability-related issues and employment or reemployment of individuals with disabilities. The Comptroller General of the United States shall submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The Comptroller General of the United States submits quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report includes the number of cases where the Secretary did not meet requirements and the number of cases where a referral request was not made within the required time period. The Comptroller General submits quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The reports detail cases where referrals were not made within the required time period or where requirements were not met. The Special Counsel received referrals under specific sections but did not meet the requirements. The Secretary is required to coordinate with other departments for uniform data categorization. The Secretary is required to coordinate with other departments to ensure uniform categorization of data in reports and electronic access to case files. The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to each report required under such section 4332 after the date of the enactment of this Act.
